lesson.name: Lesson 8.11 Teacher Guide: Writing Quadratic Equations Given Real Solutions

page.title: 8.11.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
Lesson Narrative

In earlier lessons, students factored the standard form of a quadratic function to find its solutions, or zeros. Students will now be provided the zeros of a quadratic function and convert them into the factored form and standard form of that function.

Students will also distinguish between finding a quadratic function that has certain zeros and finding the specific quadratic function that has certain zeros and passes through a particular point. They will learn to differentiate between these related quadratic functions.

Learning Goals (Teacher Facing)

Students will be able to:

  • Convert fluently between a quadratic function's zeros, its factored form, and its standard form.
  • Identify the zeros on the graph of a quadratic function and use them to write the standard form of that function.
  • Use the intercept form of a quadratic function, \(f(x) = a(x − p)(x − q)\), to define a specific function given its zeros and a point.

Learning Targets (Student Facing) 

  • Find the standard form of a quadratic function given its zeros.
  • Find the standard form of a quadratic function given its graph.
  • Use the intercept form of a quadratic function to define a specific function given its zeros and a point.

Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS)


TEKS

Explanation of Coverage

A6(C) write quadratic functions when given real solutions and graphs of their related equations.

Full coverage: Lesson provides content that covers all parts of this TEKS.

Lesson Activities

Here are the instructional activities for the lesson:

  • 8.11.1: Relating a Quadratic Function and Its Zeros
  • 8.11.2: Finding a Quadratic Function from Its Zeros
    • 8.11.2: Self Check 
    • 8.11.2: Additional Resources
  • 8.11.3: Finding a Quadratic Function from Its Zeros and a Point
    • 8.11.3: Self Check 
    • 8.11.3: Additional Resources
  • 8.11.4: Writing Quadratics When Given Any Format

Students will also complete a series of problems in the 8.11.5: Practice.

Required Materials

  • Paper and pencil
  • Graphing technology

Required Preparation

  • Acquire devices that can run Desmos (recommended) or other graphing technology. It is ideal if each student has their own device.

Lesson Vocabulary

During this lesson, it is important to:

  • Familiarize students with the vocabulary words they will see throughout the lesson.
  • Encourage students to look for these words and notice their use and meanings.
  • Encourage students to use key vocabulary words in “math talk” and their written and oral explanations.
  • Utilize a word wall. Sample cards are located here: Mathematics Vocabulary Word Wall Cards.

Vocabulary words that are emphasized in this lesson:

Previous Vocabulary

New Vocabulary
  • quadratic equation
  • quadratic function
  • factored form (of a quadratic expression)
  • standard form (of a quadratic expression)
  • variable
  • zero of the function
  • none

Support for Building Character

Throughout this unit, find ways to encourage and support students to work on cultivating their curiosity.

Here are some tips to try during this lesson:

  • The Power of Questions
  • Throughlines

You can find other tips located here in the Playbook on Curiosity from Character Lab.

page.title: 8.11.1: Relating a Quadratic Function and Its Zeros
page.contents:
Warm Up (5 minutes)

This warm up refreshes students’ ability to convert a quadratic function from standard form to factored form. It also provides practice deriving the solutions, or zeros, of a function from its factored form. 

Students will use graphing technology to analyze the graph of a quadratic function by finding the \(x\)-intercepts and zeros.

Launch

Arrange students in groups of two. Ask students to work through the questions individually, but ask their partner if they have a question. 

Student Activity

  1. Write the quadratic function \(f(x) = x^2 − 9x + 20\) in factored form.

Answer: \(f(x) = (x − 4)(x − 5)\)

  1. What are the solutions of the quadratic equation \((x − 4)(x − 5) = 0\)?

Answer: \(x = 4\) and \(x = 5\)

  1. Graph the quadratic function \(f(x) = x^2− 9x + 20\). 

Use the Desmos graphing tool or technology outside the course. 

What are the \(x\)-intercepts of the graph?

Answer: \((4, 0)\), \((5, 0)\) or 4 and 5

  1. Marcus states that the zeros of the function of \(f(x) = x^2 − 9x + 20\) are 4 and 5. Do you agree? Explain your reasoning.

Answer: Yes, 4 and 5 are the input values that result in an output of 0. When the function \(f(x) = x^2 − 9x + 20\) is graphed, it crosses the \(x\)-axis at \(x=4\) and \(x=5\).

Activity Synthesis

Ensure students understand moving from standard form to factored form to deriving solutions or zeros using a quadratic function. After students work through the questions, ask the class as a whole if there are any outstanding questions.

These are important skills that this lesson builds on as students learn more about writing a quadratic function when given its zeros.

page.title: 8.11.2: Finding a Quadratic Function from Its Zeros
page.contents:
Activity (20 minutes)

In previous lessons, students learned to derive the zeros of a quadratic function from its standard form or factored form. In this activity, students will convert from a function's zeros to its factored form and standard form. Students will also practice this process after analyzing the graph of a quadratic function.

Launch

Arrange students in groups of two. Answer questions 1–3 to familiarize students with the process of converting from zeros to the standard form of a function. Pause and allow students to ask any questions. Then allow each pair to complete questions 4–11 on their own. Emphasize that questions 9–11 are the same as the preceding questions, except that students must analyze the graph to find the zeros. 

Student Activity

In previous lessons, you learned about the relationship between a quadratic function's zeros and the binomial factors in the factored form of the equation. Use this information to answer the following questions. If needed, review activities 8.9.3 and 8.10.3.

Questions 1–3 refer to a quadratic equation that has the zeros –3 and 4. 

  1. Write the factored form of this equation set equal to zero.

Answer: \((x + 3)(x − 4) = 0\)

  1. Now, write the standard form of the same quadratic equation.

Answer: \(x^2 − x − 12 = 0\)

  1. Write the quadratic equation as the function \(f(x)\).

Answer: \(f(x) = x^2 − x − 12\)

So a quadratic equation that has the zeros –3 and 4 can be expressed as a function \(f(x) = x^2 − x − 12\).

For questions 4–8, identify a quadratic function in standard form, \(f(x)\), with the given zeros.

  1. 8 and 4

Answer: \(f(x) = x^2 − 12x + 32\)

The factored form derived from the zeros is \(f(x) = (x − 8)(x − 4)\).

  1. −6 and 3

Answer: \(f(x) = x^2 + 3x − 18\)

The factored form derived from the zeros is \(f(x) = (x + 6)(x − 3)\).

  1. \(\sqrt3\) and \(-\sqrt3\)

Answer: \(f(x) = x^2 − 3\)

The factored form derived from the zeros is \(f(x) = (x + \sqrt{3})(x − \sqrt{3})\).

  1. 5

Answer: \(f(x) = x^2 − 10x + 25\)

The factored form derived from the zeros is \(f(x) = (x − 5)(x − 5)\).

  1. −4

Answer: \(f(x) = x^2 + 8x + 16\)

The factored form derived from the zeros is \(f(x) = (x + 4)(x + 4)\).

  1. Examine the graph below, then identify a quadratic function in standard form, \(f(x)\), with the given zeros.

Answer: \(f(x) = x^2 − 2x − 24\)

The zeros are –4 and 6.

The factored form derived from the zeros is \(f(x) = (x + 4)(x − 6)\).

  1. Examine the graph below, then identify a quadratic function in standard form, \(f(x)\), with the given zeros. 

Answer: \(f(x) = x^2 − 6x + 9\)

The zero is 3.

The factored form derived from the zero is \(f(x) = (x − 3)(x − 3)\).

  1. Examine the graph below, then identify a quadratic function in standard form, \(f(x)\), with the given zeros.

Answer: \(f(x) = x^2 − 3x − 10\)

The zeros are –2 and 5.

The factored form derived from the zeros is \(f(x) = (x + 2)(x − 5)\).

Anticipated Misconceptions

Students may not remember how to approach questions 7 and 8, since they only have one solution, or zero. Remind students these are double roots, where the same solution is represented twice. If another hint is needed, tell students that in the factored form for each question, the binomial will repeat itself.

Activity Synthesis

To review key ideas from the activity, discuss the following questions:

  • "Can you convert directly from the zeros of a function to standard form?" (No, the zeros of a function can be converted into factored form, which can then be converted into standard form.)
  • "How can you convert the graph of a quadratic function into its standard form?" (Analyze the graph to find the zeros, or solutions, of the function. Use the zeros to write the function in factored form. Use FOIL to write the factored form in standard form.)

8.11.2: Self Check 

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

QUESTION: 

Identify a quadratic function, \(g(x)\), in standard form, that has the zeros 5 and –7.

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

\(g(x) = x^2 + 2x − 35\)

That's correct! Check yourself: Substitute the zeros in for \(x\) and check to see the function equals 0. \( (5)^2 + 2(5) − 35 = 0\), and \((-7)^2 + 2(-7) − 35 = 0\).

\(g(x) = x^2 − 2x + 35\)

Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: The factored form of the quadratic function is \(g(x) = (x − 5)(x + 7)\). Use the distributive property, or FOIL, to find the answer. The answer is \(g(x) = x^2 + 2x − 35\).

\(g(x) = x^2 + 12x + 35\)

Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: The factored form of the quadratic function is \(g(x) = (x − 5)(x + 7)\). Use the distributive property, or FOIL, to find the answer. The answer is \(g(x) = x^2 + 2x − 35\).

\(g(x) = x^2 − 12x + 35\)

Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: The factored form of the quadratic function is \(g(x) = (x − 5)(x + 7)\). Use the distributive property, or FOIL, to find the answer. The answer is \(g(x) = x^2 + 2x − 35\).

8.11.2: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it. 

Finding a Quadratic Function from Its Zeros

Given the zeros of a quadratic function, we can write it in standard form.

Let's look at an example.

Example 1

Write a function, \(h(x)\), that has the zeros 5 and –3. 

We know that if the zeros are 5 and –3, then the factor equations that were solved are:

 \(x − 5 = 0\)     and      \(x + 3 = 0\).

When these equations are solved, they provide the zeros 5 and –3.

We can use these equations to write the function in factored form. 

\(h(x) = (x − 5)(x + 3)\)

By using the distributive property, or FOIL, we can find the standard form of the function.

\(h(x) = x^2 − 2x − 15\)

Recall that sometimes a function might have only one zero.

Example 2

Write a function, \(d(x)\), that has one zero at 8. 

From previous lessons, we know that when the factor equations were identical, there was only one zero.

\(x − 8 = 0\)     and      \(x − 8 = 0\)

The factored form of this equation is \(d(x) = (x − 8)(x − 8)\).

After using the distributive property, or FOIL, the standard form of the function is \(d(x) = x^2 − 16x + 64\).

Finding the zeros from a graph follows the same process.

Example 3

Write a function, \(z(x)\), that corresponds to the graph shown.

The zeros of the graph are –4 and –1. The resulting factor equations are:

\(x + 4 = 0\)     and      \(x + 1 = 0\).

The factored form of this equation is \(z(x) = (x + 4)(x + 1)\).

After using FOIL, the standard form of the function is \(z(x) = x^2 + 5x + 4\).

Try It: Finding a Quadratic Function from Its Zeros

  1. Identify a quadratic function in standard form, \(f(x)\), with zeros –6 and 1.
  2. Identify a quadratic function in standard form, \(f(x)\), with the zero –9.
  3. Identify a quadratic function in standard form, \(f(x)\), with the given zeros.

Write down your answers, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Solution

Here is how to find the standard form of the quadratic functions:

  1. \(x = -6\) and \(x = 1\)
    \(f(x) = (x + 6)(x − 1)\)
    \(f(x) = x^2 + 5x − 6\)
  1. \(x = -9\)
    \(f(x) = (x + 9)(x + 9)\)
    \(f(x) = x^2 + 18x + 81\)
  1. The zeros of the graph are \(x = 3\) and \(x = 7\).
    \(f(x) = (x − 3)(x − 7)\)
    \(f(x) = x^2 − 10x + 21\)

page.title: 8.11.3: Finding a Quadratic Function from Its Zeros and a Point
page.contents:
Activity (20 minutes)

This activity introduces students to finding a specific quadratic equation that has certain zeros and passes through a particular point. In previous lessons, students found a quadratic function that has certain zeros in its simplest standard form. In this activity, students will find a more specific quadratic function using the given point.

This is accomplished by using the intercept form, \(f(x) = a(x − p)(x − q)\), of a quadratic equation. The roots of the function and the given point are substituted into the function to find the value of \(a\). This value of the multiplier, \(a\), is then distributed through the equation to find the specific quadratic equation that meets our given criteria.

Launch

In this activity, questions 1–3 provide a step-through introduction to finding the specific equation of a quadratic equation that has certain zeros and passes through a given point. Give students time to complete the first three questions and then pause for a class discussion.

While discussing the first three questions, emphasize that the function \(m(x) = x^2− 3x − 40\) is a function that has the zeros –5 and 8. As we found in question 3, \(m(x) = 2x^2− 6x − 80\) is another function that has the zeros –5 and 8. Only the function \(m(x) = 2x^2− 6x − 80\) passes through the point \((5, -60)\) and is the specific function we want. Show the graphs of these two functions using Desmos to help visualize the difference between these two quadratic equations. Emphasize that these quadratic equations are related since they both have the same zeros and axis of symmetry (\(x = 1.5)\). Only one of them, however, passes through the point \((5, -60)\).

Allow students to complete questions 4–6 in pairs. 

Student Activity

When finding an exact function that has particular zeros and passes through a certain point, we use the intercept form of a quadratic function:

\(f(x) = a(x − p)(x − q)\)

The variables \(p\) and \(q\) represent the zeros or roots of the function. The variable \(a\) accounts for any constant that might have been factored out when solving.

  1. Find a function, \(m(x)\), in intercept form, that has the zeros –5 and 8.

Answer: The intercept form is \(m(x) = a(x − (-5))(x − 8)\). 

\(= a(x + 5)(x − 8)\) 

Let's use the intercept form of the function above to find the exact function that passes through \((5, -60)\).

  1. First, find the value of \(a\). To do this, substitute the values of the point into the intercept form of the function.

Answer:
\(m(x) = a(x + 5)(x − 8)\) 
\(-60 = a((5) + 5)((5) − 8)\) 
\(-60 = a(10)(-3)\) 
\(-60 = -30a\)
  \(2 = a\)

  1. Substitute the value of \(a\) into the intercept form of the function and multiply to find the standard form.

Answer:
\(m(x) = a(x + 5)(x − 8)\) 
\(m(x) = 2(x + 5)(x − 8)\)
\(m(x) = 2(x^2 + 5x − 8x − 40)\)
\(m(x) = 2(x^2 − 3x − 40)\)
\(m(x) = 2x^2 − 6x − 80\)

This is the function with zeros –5 and 8 that passes through \((5, -60)\).

  1. Write the quadratic function, \(n(x)\), in standard form, that has the zeros 9 and –2 and passes through the point \((0, -36)\).

Answer: \(n(x) = 2x^2 − 14x − 36\)

  1. Write the quadratic function, \(p(x)\), in standard form, that has the zeros –6 and –4 and passes through the point \((-5, 3)\).

Answer: \(p(x) = −3x^2 − 30x − 72\)

  1. Write the quadratic function, \(c(x)\), in standard form, that has the zeros 1 and 7 and passes through the point \((9, 16)\).

Answer: \(c(x) = x^2 − 8x + 7\)

Video: Finding a Quadratic Function from Its Zeros and a Point

Watch the following video to learn more about finding a quadratic function from its zeros and a point. 



Activity Synthesis

To summarize key ideas from the activity, discuss the following questions:

  • “In this activity, what does it mean for two quadratic equations to be related?” (Two quadratic functions are related if they have the same zeros and the same axis of symmetry.)
  • “How can you use the intercept form of a quadratic equation such as \(f(x) = a(x − 5)(x − 4)\) and a point that it passes through to find the value of \(a\)?” (Substitute the point into the function and solve for the value of \(a\). Substitute the value of \(a\) back into the equation and multiply to find the standard form of the quadratic equation.)

8.11.3: Self Check 

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

QUESTION: 

Write the quadratic function, \(z(x)\), in standard form, that has the zeros –1 and 8 and passes through the point \((0, 16)\).

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

\(z(x) = −2x^2 + 14x + 16\)

That's correct! Check yourself: Substitute the points \((-1, 0)\), \((8, 0)\), and \((0, 16)\) into the function and check that each is true. Since each one is true, the answer is correct.

\(z(x) = 3x^2 − 21x − 24\)

Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: This is an incorrect value \(a\), in which \(a = 3\). The correct value of \(a\) is –2. The answer is \(z(x) = −2x^2 + 14x +16\).

\(z(x) = 2x^2 − 14x − 16\)

Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: This is an incorrect value \(a\), in which \(a = 2\). The correct value of \(a\) is –2. The answer is \(z(x) = −2x^2 + 14x +16\).

\(z(x) = x^2 + 7x + 8\)

Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: This is the standard form of the function without finding the value of \(a\). Use the intercept form and the point \((0, 16)\) to find the value of \(a\). The answer is \(z(x) = −2x^2 + 14x +16\).

8.11.3: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it. 

Finding a Quadratic Function from Its Zeros and a Point

Think about how you would solve the quadratic equation \(x^2 − 3x + 2 = 0\).

  • The factored form is \((x − 1)(x − 2) = 0\).
  • The solutions are \(x = 1\) and \(x = 2\).

Now think about how you would solve \(2x^2 − 6x + 4 = 0\).

  • Factor out the GCF, 2.

\(2(x^2 − 3x + 2) = 0\)

It looks similar to the previous quadratic equation.

  • The factored form is \(2(x − 1)(x − 2) = 0\).
  • Once again, the solutions are \(x = 1\) and \(x = 2\).

Since they have the same solutions, these two quadratic equations are related. They have the same zeros and the same axis of symmetry. 

When we are reversing this process, going from the zeros of a quadratic function to finding its standard form, it is possible there is a multiplier, such as 2 in the example above, that we do not know about.

To account for this, we use the variable \(a\) as the multiplier until we find out exactly what it is.

We can incorporate \(a\) into the function using the intercept form, \(f(x) = a(x − p)(x − q)\). The variables \(p\) and \(q\) represent the zeros or roots of the function.

Let's look at an example to help us understand.

Example 1

Write the quadratic function, \(f(x)\), that has the zeros –5 and 4 and passes through the point \((-4, -16)\).

We know the zeros are –5 and 4, so the factored form of the quadratic function is:

\(f(x) = (x + 5)(x − 4)\).

The intercept form is \(f(x) = a(x + 5)(x − 4)\).

We are given one more piece of information that allows us to find the value of \(a\). We know that the function passes through the point \((-4, -16)\).

We can substitute –4 for \(x\) and –16 for the value of the function and solve for \(a\).

\(f(x) = a(x + 5)(x − 4)\)

\(-16 = a((-4) + 5)((-4) − 4)\)

\(-16 = a(1)(-8)\)

\(-16 = -8a\)

\(2 = a\)

Since we know \(a = 2\), we can substitute 2 for \(a\) into the intercept form of the quadratic function.

\(f(x) = a(x + 5)(x − 4)\)

\(f(x) = 2(x + 5)(x − 4)\)

\(f(x) = 2(x^2 + 5x − 4x − 20)\)

\(f(x) = 2(x^2 + x − 20)\)

\(f(x) = 2x^2 + 2x − 40\)

The specific function that has zeros –5 and 4 and passes through the point \((-4, -16)\) is:

\(f(x) = 2x^2 + 2x − 40\).

Let's graph the functions to check our work.

Notice that \(f(x) = x^2 + x − 20\) and \(f(x) = 2x^2 + 2x − 40\) have the same zeros. These quadratic functions are related.

Only \(f(x) = 2x^2 + 2x − 40\) passes through \((-4, -16)\) and is the specific function we were looking for at the start.

It is very important to note that this is why, in the previous lesson, we were looking for “a function that has zeros at –5 and 4” and not “the function that has zeros at –5 and 4.” 

This difference in wording is very important since there are infinitely many functions that are related by their solutions.

We can only determine an exact specific function if we have the additional information of a point through which the function passes.

Let's try one more example. 

Example 2

Write the quadratic function, \(g(x)\), in standard form, that has the zeros –7 and –3 and passes through the point \((-2, -5)\).

Since the zeros are –7 and –3, the factored form of the function is \(g(x) = (x + 7)(x + 3)\).

The intercept form of the function is \(g(x) = a(x + 7)(x + 3)\).

We substitute values using the point \((-2, -5)\) to find the value of \(a\).

\(g(x) = a(x + 7)(x + 3)\)

\(-5 = a((-2) + 7)((-2) + 3)\)

\(-5 = a(5)(1)\)

\(-5 = 5a\)

\(-1 = a\)

Substitute the value of \(a\) into the intercept form of the function.

\(g(x) = a(x + 7)(x + 3)\)

\(g(x) = -1(x + 7)(x + 3)\)

\(g(x) = -1(x^2 + 7x + 3x + 21)\)

\(g(x) = -1(x^2 + 10x + 21)\)

\(g(x) = -x^2 − 10x − 21\)

The specific function that has zeros –7 and –3 and passes through the point \((-2, -5)\) is:

\(g(x) = -x^2 − 10x − 21\).

Let's graph the functions to check our work.

Again, notice that \(g(x) = x^2 + 10x + 21\) and \(g(x) = −x^2 − 10x − 21\) have the same zeros. They are related quadratic functions.

Even though the leading coefficient is negative and the function has been reflected over the \(x\)-axis, only \(g(x) = −x^2 − 10x − 21\) passes through \((-2, -5)\).

Try It: Finding a Quadratic Function from Its Zeros and a Point

Write the quadratic function, \(h(x)\), that has the zeros 2 and 6 and passes through the point \((7, 15)\).

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Solution

Here is how to find a function when given its zeros and a point:

The zeros are 2 and 6.

The intercept form is \(h(x) = a(x − 2)(x − 6)\).

Use the point \((7, 15)\) to find \(a\).

\(h(x) = a(x − 2)(x − 6)\)

\(15 = a((7) − 2)((7) − 6)\)

\(15 = a(5)(1)\)

\(3 = a\)

Substitute 3 for the value of \(a\) in the intercept form.

\(h(x) = a(x − 2)(x − 6)\)

\(h(x) = 3(x^2 − 2x − 6x + 12)\)

\(h(x) = 3(x^2 − 8x + 12)\)

\(h(x) = 3x^2 − 24x + 36\)

The specific quadratic with zeros of 2 and 6 that passes through the point \((7, 15)\) is \(h(x) = 3x^2 − 24x + 36\).

page.title: 8.11.4: Writing Quadratics When Given Any Format
page.contents:
Cool Down (5 minutes)

Student Activity

In this lesson, you have learned how to write a quadratic function from different starting contexts and when provided different information.

  1. Identify a quadratic function in standard form, \(b(x)\), with the zeros –6 and 8.

Answer: \(b(x) = x^2 − 2x − 48\)

  1. Identify a quadratic function in standard form, \(m(x)\), with the given zero.

Answer: \(m(x) = x^2 − 12x + 36\)

  1. Write the specific quadratic function, \(d(x)\), in standard form, that has the zeros 2 and 5 and passes through the point \((1, 16)\).

Answer: Intercept form: \(d(x) = a(x − 2)(x − 5)\)

Find the value of \(a\). Use point \((1, 16)\).

\(d(x) = a(x − 2)(x − 5)\)
\(16 = a((1) − 2)((1) − 5)\)
\(16 = a(-1)(-4)\)
\(16 = 4a\)
\(4 = a\)

Substitute 4 for \(a\).

\(d(x) = a(x − 2)(x − 5)\)
\(d(x) = 4(x − 2)(x − 5)\)
\(d(x) = 4(x^2 − 2x − 5x + 10)\)
\(d(x) = 4(x^2 − 7x + 10)\)
\(d(x) = 4x^2 − 28x + 40\)

So, the specific quadratic function written in standard form is \(d(x) = 4x^2 − 28x + 40\).

page.title: 8.11.5: Practice
page.contents:
Students will complete the following questions to practice the skills they have learned in this lesson.

For questions 1–6, identify a quadratic function in standard form, \(f(x)\), with the given zeros.

  1. 1 and 9
  • \(f(x) = x^2 + 10x + 9\)
  • \(f(x) = x^2 − 8x + 9\)
  • \(f(x) = x^2 + 8x + 9\)
  • \(f(x) = x^2 − 10x + 9\)

Answer: \(f(x) = x^2 − 10x + 9\)

  1. \(\sqrt5\) and \(-\sqrt{5}\)
  • \(f(x) = x^2 − 5x − 5\)
  • \(f(x) = x^2 + 5x − 5\)
  • \(f(x) = x^2 − 5\)
  • \(f(x) = x^2 + 5\)

Answer: \(f(x) = x^2 − 5\)

  1. –7
  • \(f(x) = x^2 + 14x + 49\)
  • \(f(x) = x^2 − 14x − 49\)
  • \(f(x) = x^2 − 49\)
  • \(f(x) = x^2 − 14x + 49\)

Answer: \(f(x) = x^2 + 14x + 49\)

  1. Examine the graph below to identify the zeros of the function. Then, write a quadratic function in standard form with the given zeros.

    

  • \(f(x) = x^2 + 4x − 5\)
  • \(f(x) = x^2 − 6x − 5\)
  • \(f(x) = x^2 − 4x − 5\)
  • \(f(x) = x^2 + 6x − 5\)

Answer: \(f(x) = x^2 + 4x − 5\)

  1. –3
  • \(f(x) = x^2 − 6x + 9\)
  • \(f(x) = x^2 + 9\)
  • \(f(x) = x^2 + 6x + 9\)
  • \(f(x) = x^2 − 9\)

Answer: \(f(x) = x^2 + 6x + 9\)

  1. Examine the graph below to identify the zeros of the function. Then, write a quadratic function in standard form with the given zeros.

  • \(f(x) = x^2 − 2x − 8\)
  • \(f(x) = x^2 − 6x + 8\)
  • \(f(x) = x^2 + 2x − 8\)
  • \(f(x) = x^2 + 6x + 8\)

Answer: \(f(x) = x^2 − 6x + 8\)

  1. Write the specific quadratic function, \(p(x)\), in standard form, that has the zeros –8 and 3 and passes through the point \((2, -20)\).
  • \(p(x) = 2x^2 + 10x − 48\)
  • \(p(x) = 3x^2 + 15x − 72\)
  • \(p(x) = −x^2 − 5x − 6\)
  • \(p(x) = x^2 + 5x − 24\)

Answer: \(p(x) = 2x^2 + 10x − 48\)

  1. Write the specific quadratic function, \(g(x)\), in standard form, that has the zero 2 and passes through the point \((3, -3)\).
  • \(g(x) = x^2 − 4x + 4\)
  • \(g(x) = 2x^2 − 8x + 3\)
  • \(g(x) = −2x^2 + 8x − 8\)
  • \(g(x) = −3x^2 + 12x − 12\)

Answer: \(g(x) = −3x^2 + 12x − 12\)

  1. Write the specific quadratic function, \(h(x)\), in standard form, that has the zeros 3 and 5 and passes through the point \((2, 12)\).
  • \(h(x) = x^2 − 8x + 15\)
  • \(h(x) = 4x^2 − 32x + 60\)
  • \(h(x) = −x^2 + 8x − 15\)
  • \(h(x) = 3x^2 − 24x + 48\)

Answer: \(h(x) = 4x^2 − 32x + 60\)

  1. Write the specific quadratic function, \(w(x)\), in standard form, that has the zeros 6 and –7 and passes through the point \((5, 12)\).
  • \(w(x) = x^2 + x − 42\)
  • \(w(x) = 2x^2 + 2x − 48\)
  • \(w(x) = −2x^2 − 2x + 84\)
  • \( w(x) = −x^2 − x + 42\)

Answer: \(w(x) = −x^2 − x + 42\)

page.title: 8.11.6: Lesson Synthesis
page.contents:
To help students summarize key points from the lesson, discuss questions such as:

  • "How would you find the standard form of a quadratic function by analyzing its graph?" (Analyze its graph to determine the zeros of the function. Use the zeros of the function to write the function in factored form. Convert the factored form of the function into standard form.)
  • "Can two different functions have the same zeros?" (Yes. Related quadratic functions have the same zeros and the same axis of symmetry when graphed.)
  • "Describe in your own words how to find a specific quadratic function from its zeros and a point that it contains." (Use the zeros to find a function’s intercept form using \(a\) as the multiplier. Substitute the point into the function and solve for the value of \(a\). Substitute that value back into the intercept form of the equation and distribute the value.)
